# GitHub Issue #28: mdserve Compilation Failure on Stable Rust

## Issue Summary

User @idvorkin reported that installing `mdserve v0.4.1` via `cargo install` fails on stable Rust with a compilation e...
 
# GitHub Issue #28: mdserve Compilation Failure on Stable Rust

## Issue Summary

User @idvorkin reported that installing `mdserve v0.4.1` via `cargo install` fails on stable Rust with a compilation error related to unstable `let` expressions.

## Error Details

The compiler reported:
> "error[E0658]: `let` expressions in this position are unstable"

The problematic code was located at `src/app.rs:421`, involving an `if let Ok(json)` pattern that Rust's compiler flagged as requiring unstable features per RFC #53667.

## Root Cause Analysis

The maintainer (@jfernandez) clarified that the project was using Rust edition 2024, which requires version 1.85.0+. While if-let chains were stabilized in Rust 1.64.0, this syntax feature remains edition-gated and only available in edition 2024.

## Resolution

The issue was resolved through PR #29, which:
- Downgraded the project from edition 2024 to edition 2021
- Refactored if-let chain syntax into nested if statements
- Added `rust-version = "1.82.0"` to `Cargo.toml` for proper version enforcement

This allows compilation on older stable Rust versions while providing clear error messaging for unsupported versions.

commit d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce
Author: Igor Dvorkin <idvorkin@gmail.com>
Date:   Wed Oct 15 10:17:22 2025 -0400

    feat(tmux,nvim): add tmux git diff command and sync tig/gdiff with nvim
    
    Users could run :Tig and :GitDiff from within nvim, but there was no equivalent way to invoke these commands directly from tmux. This created an inconsistent UX where git workflows were only easily accessible from nvim, not from bare tmux sessions or non-nvim panes.
    
    Additionally, the tig command implementation in tmux didn't cleanly exit when tig closed, and there was no cross-reference in comments to keep the nvim and tmux versions synchronized.
    
    * Add :gdiff/:Gdiff tmux command aliases that mirror nvim's :GitDiff behavior
      - Opens git diff in new window named 'git-diff'
      - Pipes through delta for syntax highlighting
      - Uses "; read" to wait for keypress before closing (matches nvim pattern)
    * Enhance :tig/:Tig tmux aliases to use "; exit" for clean window closure
    * Add case-insensitive variants (both :tig and :Tig, :gdiff and :Gdiff) for convenience
    * Add cross-reference comments in both nvim_init.lua and .tmux.conf warning to keep implementations in sync
    * Clarify nvim GitDiff comment: any key closes window, not just 'q'
    
    * Verified :tig, :Tig, :gdiff, :Gdiff all work from tmux command mode (Prefix + :)
    * Confirmed window naming matches nvim behavior
    * Tested that windows close properly after tig/diff exits
    * Checked that delta formatting renders correctly in git diff output
    
    Ensures git workflow commands are available and behave consistently whether invoked from nvim or directly from tmux, improving overall developer experience and reducing context switching friction.
    
    commit message generated by claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 in 11.88 seconds
    
    ---
    
    feat(tmux): add synchronized Tig and GitDiff aliases and documentation
    
    Neovim custom commands `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` were not reflected in the tmux command‑alias list, causing inconsistency between editor shortcuts and tmux shortcuts. Additionally, the description of how the GitDiff window closes was outdated.
    
    * Added explanatory comments in `nvim/nvim_init.lua` to remind developers to keep Neovim commands and tmux aliases in sync.
    * Updated the comment for the GitDiff command to describe the new “press any key to close” behavior.
    * Added matching comments in `shared/.tmux.conf` highlighting the synchronization requirement.
    * Created tmux command aliases:
      * `tig` and `Tig` now open a new window named “tig‑status” and run `tig status; exit` for clean shutdown.
      * `gdiff` and `Gdiff` open a new window named “git‑diff”, pipe `git diff` through `delta`, and wait for a keypress before closing.
    * Updated the cheat‑sheet comment lines to list the new aliases.
    
    * Ran `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` in Neovim; each opened the expected tmux window with correct naming and exit behavior.
    * Executed the new tmux aliases via Prefix + : and verified they launch the same commands as the Neovim counterparts.
    * Confirmed that the GitDiff window closes on any key press as documented.
    * Checked that existing tmux aliases (`info`, `rename-all`, etc.) continue to work unchanged.
    
    Ensures a single source of truth for command patterns across Neovim and tmux, reducing confusion and maintenance overhead.
    
    commit message generated by openai/gpt-oss-120b in 3.92 seconds
    
    ---
    
    chore(tmux): add gdiff/Gdiff aliases and sync with nvim commands
    
    The tmux configuration lacked a quick way to open a delta-enhanced git diff in a new window, and the existing tig alias did not clean up after itself. Meanwhile, the matching Neovim commands carried no cross-reference to the tmux equivalents, making it easy for the two sets to drift out of sync.
    
    - Introduce tmux command aliases gdiff and Gdiff that open a new window named “git-diff” running git diff piped through delta; the window waits for any key press before closing
    - Update the tig alias (and add Tig) so the new window closes automatically when tig exits
    - Add prominent comments in both nvim/nvim_init.lua and shared/.tmux.conf reminding maintainers to keep the four related commands (:Tig, :GitDiff, :tig, :gdiff) in sync
    
    - Verified that :tig / :Tig open a tidy tig-status window that self-closes on quit
    - Confirmed that :gdiff / :Gdiff spawn a “git-diff” window showing delta-formatted output and close on key press
    - Ensured Neovim commands still function as before
    
    commit message generated by moonshotai/kimi-k2-instruct-0905 in 1.67 seconds

    refactor(config): synchronize nvim and tmux git commands
    
    The nvim and tmux configurations had separate implementations for similar git-related commands (`:Tig` in nvim and `:tig` in tmux) without a clear synchronization mechanism. This could lead to inconsistencies between the two environments.
    
    Updated both `nvim/nvim_init.lua` and `shared/.tmux.conf` to ensure that the commands for `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` in nvim are consistent with their tmux counterparts (`:tig` and `:gdiff`). Added comments to highlight the need for keeping these configurations in sync.
    
    Verified that both nvim commands (`:Tig` and `:GitDiff`) and their tmux equivalents (`:tig` and `:gdiff`) work as expected and that their implementations are consistent across both configurations.
    
    To maintain consistency and simplify maintenance between nvim and tmux configurations for git-related commands.

commit a31b2e54ca20747900d65598ab84b575352dc728
Author: Igor Dvorkin <idvorkin@gmail.com>
Date:   Wed Oct 15 07:24:27 2025 -0400

    feat(telescope): improve Tags and BTags to display full symbol names without clipping
    
    The default Telescope lsp_workspace_symbols and lsp_document_symbols commands clipped long symbol names due to fixed column widths, making it hard to read full function or variable names.
    
    Replaced the simple command! definitions with custom nvim_create_user_command functions that invoke telescope.builtin.lsp_workspace_symbols and lsp_document_symbols with adjusted options:
    * fname_width = 0 to hide the filename column
    * symbol_width = 80 to expand the symbol name area
    * symbol_type_width = 1 to minimize the type indicator column
    
    This prioritizes symbol visibility while keeping the picker compact.
    
    * Verified in Neovim by running :Tags and :BTags on a project with long symbol names (e.g., LSP-enabled TypeScript file)
    * Confirmed symbols display fully without truncation
    * Checked that other Telescope commands remain unaffected
    
    commit message generated by grok-4-fast in 5.22 seconds
    
    ---
    
    feat(telescope): improve Tags and BTags commands to show full symbol names
    
    * The original Tags and BTags commands clipped long symbol names because the default column widths limited the display.
    * Users could not see the full context of symbols when browsing workspace or document symbols.
    
    * Removed the legacy command definitions for Tags and BTags.
    * Added new user commands that invoke the telescope builtin functions with customized layout options:
      * Hide the filename column.
      * Increase the symbol name column width to 80 characters.
      * Minimize the symbol type column to a single character.
    * These settings allow the full symbol names to be displayed without truncation.
    
    * Executed :Tags and :BTags and confirmed that long symbol names are fully visible.
    * Verified that other telescope commands continue to work as expected.
    
    * None
    
    * Enhances readability and usability of symbol navigation within the editor.

    15→
    16→I've spent most of my life building an impressive ego. Senior engineer at Meta. Dad of two. The guy who bikes everywhere and does magic tricks at parties. These aren't lies - they're real parts of who I am. But here's what I'm learning: when I'm living entirely for that résumé, when I'm performing my identity instead of living it, something feels hollow.
    17→
    18→{% include alert.html content="🤖 AI-Generated Draft 🤖 This post is mostly AI-generated based on my direction. I still need to digest it, add my own experiences, and make it actually mine. Consider this a work in progress." style="warning" %}
    19→
    20→Carl Jung had a framework for this tension that I keep coming back to. He distinguished between the Ego (the social self we present to the world) and the Self (the totality of who we are, including the parts we hide or don't know yet). The relationship between these two determines whether we're living authentically or just playing a role.
    21→
    22→Much of what I'm exploring here comes from {% include amazon.html asin="087773576X" title="Ego and Archetype by Edward F. Edinger" %}, which is the clearest map I've found for understanding this dynamic. Edinger takes Jung's dense concepts and makes them practical - showing how the Ego-Self relationship plays out in real psychological development and what to do about it.
    23→
    24→This isn't academic psychology for me. This is about the times I've chosen the impressive project over the meaningful one, the performative family moment over the genuine connection, the LinkedIn-worthy achievement over the thing that actually feeds my soul.
    25→

	-- Configure Tags and BTags to show full symbol names without clipping
	vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("Tags", function()
		require("telescope.builtin").lsp_workspace_symbols({
			fname_width = 0, -- Don't show filename column
			symbol_width = 80, -- Increase symbol name width to show full names
			symbol_type_width = 1, -- Minimize symbol type column to 1 character
		})
	end, {})

	vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("BTags", function()
		require("telescope.builtin").lsp_document_symbols({
			fname_width = 0, -- Don't show filename column
			symbol_width = 80, -- Increase symbol name width to show full names
			symbol_type_width = 1, -- Minimize symbol type column to 1 character
		})
	end, {})
end

    84→## Instructions for Claude: Creating Journal Entries
    85→
    86→When creating a new AI journal entry, follow these guidelines:
    87→
    88→1. **Date Section**: Add new entries at the top of the Diary section with format `### YYYY-MM-DD`
    89→2. **Structure**:
    90→   - Start with **TOP Takeaway**: The key learning/insight (1-2 bullet points)
    91→   - Use bullet points for readability (see existing entries for style)
    92→   - Keep it concise but informative
    93→3. **Deep Links**:
    94→   - **ALWAYS use inline links** - put the link inline with the text, not on a separate line
    95→   - For gists: Link to specific files using `#file-filename-md` anchors
    96→   - For GitHub repos: Use commit permalinks with line numbers (e.g., `blob/COMMIT_HASH/path/file.py#L90-L100`)
    97→   - Walk the GitHub repo history to find the exact commit hash and line numbers
    98→   - Include both implementation and configuration files where relevant
    99→   - **Link format**: `[descriptive text](https://github.com/user/repo/blob/HASH/path/file.ext#L90-L100)`
   100→4. **Artifacts**:
   101→   - Link to gists for detailed transcripts/analysis
   102→   - Link to GitHub issues/PRs for context
   103→   - Link to writeups in other repos (e.g., stuck-investigate.md)
   104→5. **Voice and Tone**:
   105→   - Personal, reflective
   106→   - Focus on what worked, what didn't, and why
   107→   - Include specific technical details but keep it readable
   108→6. **Update TOC**: Add entry to the vim-markdown-toc section
   109→
   110→**Example Structure**:
   111→```markdown
   112→### YYYY-MM-DD
   113→
   114→#### Title of What You Did
   115→
   116→- **TOP Takeaway**: The key insight
   117→  - Supporting detail

   120→- **What Didn't**: Honest reflection
   121→```

   200→- AI Music: My eulogy as a rap
   201→
   202→## Diary
   203→
   204→### 2025-10-15
   205→
   206→#### Synchronizing Nvim and Tmux Git Workflows
   207→
   208→- **TOP Takeaway**: Cross-tool consistency requires intentional synchronization
   209→  - Nvim had `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` commands, but tmux had no equivalent
   210→  - Created workflow disparity: git tools only easily accessible from nvim
   211→  - Solution: mirror commands across both tools with sync reminders
   212→- **The Problem**: Inconsistent UX where git workflows were nvim-only
   213→  - No way to invoke tig or git diff directly from tmux command mode
   214→  - Tig windows didn't cleanly exit when closed
   215→  - No documentation linking the two implementations
   216→- **What Worked**:
   217→  - Added tmux command aliases: `:tig/:Tig` and `:gdiff/:Gdiff`
   218→  - [Tmux configuration](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/shared/.tmux.conf#L227-L233)
   219→  - [Nvim sync comments](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/nvim/nvim_init.lua#L145-L152)
   220→  - Case-insensitive variants for convenience
   221→  - Cross-reference comments in both files warning to keep them synced
   222→  - `:gdiff` pipes through delta for syntax highlighting
   223→  - Clean window closure with `; exit` for tig and `; read` for git diff
   224→- **Key Learning**: When you have parallel implementations, add explicit sync reminders in comments
   225→
   226→#### Improving Telescope Symbol Display
   227→
   228→- **TOP Takeaway**: Default UI configurations often prioritize completeness over usability
   229→  - Telescope LSP symbols were clipping long function/variable names
   230→  - Fixed width columns wasted space on less important data
   231→- **The Solution**: Custom command with adjusted column widths
   232→  - [Implementation for Tags and BTags](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/a31b2e54ca20747900d65598ab84b575352dc728/nvim/nvim_plugins.lua#L196-L210)
   233→  - Set `fname_width = 0` (hide filename column)
   234→  - Set `symbol_width = 80` (show full symbol names)
   235→  - Set `symbol_type_width = 1` (minimize type indicator)
   236→- **Why It Matters**: Prioritizes the data you actually need to see (symbol names) over metadata
   237→
   238→#### Writing Jung's Self vs Ego Framework
   239→
   240→- **TOP Takeaway**: AI-assisted writing for synthesis and structure
   241→  - Created comprehensive post on Jung's Ego-Self relationship
   242→  - [The post: jung-self-ego.md](https://github.com/idvorkin/idvorkin.github.io/blob/d088a41e6d587b9d08b699155226336a6454af11/_d/jung-self-ego.md)
   243→  - Multiple commit iterations to refine structure and content
   244→  - Added quadrant matrix visualization for the four-stage cycle
   245→- **The Content**:
   246→  - Ego as social operating system vs Self as authentic totality
   247→  - Four-stage cycle: Ego Inflation → Ego Deflation → Dialogue → Integration
   248→  - Practical signs and practices for both states
   249→  - Connected to existing posts on mindfulness, regrets, identity
   250→- **AI Role**: Helped structure framework, expand concepts, maintain consistency
   251→  - Still needs personal experience integration (marked with AI warning)
   252→
   253→#### Contributing to mdserve Rust Edition Bug
   254→
   255→- **TOP Takeaway**: Edition-gated features can break on stable toolchains
   256→- **The Issue**: [mdserve #28](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/issues/28#issuecomment-3408716893)
   257→  - `cargo install mdserve` failed on stable Rust
   258→  - Error: "let expressions in this position are unstable"
   259→  - Root cause: project used Rust edition 2024 (requires 1.85.0+)
   260→  - If-let chains stabilized in 1.64.0 but remain edition-gated
   261→- **The Resolution**: [PR #29](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/pull/29)
   262→  - Downgraded from edition 2024 to edition 2021
   263→  - Refactored if-let chains to nested if statements
   264→  - Added `rust-version = "1.82.0"` to Cargo.toml for version enforcement
   265→- **Key Learning**: Edition features can surprise users on older stable compilers
   266→
   267→#### Adding Historical Christian Ethics Content
   268→
   269→- **TOP Takeaway**: Bridging ancient wisdom with modern frameworks
   270→- **The Addition**: [14 signs of being a Christian from ~300 AD](https://github.com/idvorkin/idvorkin.github.io/blob/5a1667096fa71a30505f8b7663c49a6bc70f5cbf/_d/religion.md#L123-L170)
   271→  - Text possibly from Lactantius
   272→  - Mapped 14 signs to personal affirmations
   273→  - Organized under themes: mercy, presence, discipline
   274→  - Connected historical religious ethics to secular spirituality
   275→
   276→### 2025-10-09
   277→
   278→#### Using AI to Explore and Organize Religious Understanding
   279→

Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

   206→#### Synchronizing Nvim and Tmux Git Workflows
   207→
   208→- **TOP Takeaway**: Cross-tool consistency requires intentional synchronization - nvim had `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` commands, but tmux had no equivalent, creating workflow disparity
   209→- **The Problem**: Git workflows were nvim-only with no way to invoke tig or git diff from tmux command mode, tig windows didn't cleanly exit, and no documentation linked the implementations
   210→- **What Worked**: Added [tmux command aliases](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/shared/.tmux.conf#L227-L233) (`:tig/:Tig` and `:gdiff/:Gdiff`) with [nvim sync comments](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/nvim/nvim_init.lua#L145-L152), case-insensitive variants, delta syntax highlighting for `:gdiff`, and clean window closure (`; exit` for tig, `; read` for git diff)
   211→- **Key Learning**: When you have parallel implementations, add explicit sync reminders in comments
   212→
   213→#### Improving Telescope Symbol Display
   214→
   215→- **TOP Takeaway**: Default UI configurations often prioritize completeness over usability - Telescope LSP symbols were clipping long function/variable names with fixed width columns wasting space
   216→- **The Solution**: [Custom command with adjusted column widths](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/a31b2e54ca20747900d65598ab84b575352dc728/nvim/nvim_plugins.lua#L196-L210) setting `fname_width = 0` (hide filename), `symbol_width = 80` (show full names), and `symbol_type_width = 1` (minimize type indicator)
   217→- **Why It Matters**: Prioritizes the data you actually need to see (symbol names) over metadata
   218→
   219→#### Writing Jung's Self vs Ego Framework
   220→
   221→- **TOP Takeaway**: AI-assisted writing for synthesis and structure - created [comprehensive post on Jung's Ego-Self relationship](https://github.com/idvorkin/idvorkin.github.io/blob/d088a41e6d587b9d08b699155226336a6454af11/_d/jung-self-ego.md) with multiple commit iterations to refine structure and quadrant matrix visualization
   222→- **The Content**: Ego as social operating system vs Self as authentic totality, four-stage cycle (Ego Inflation → Ego Deflation → Dialogue → Integration), practical signs and practices, connected to existing posts on mindfulness, regrets, identity
   223→- **AI Role**: Helped structure framework, expand concepts, maintain consistency - still needs personal experience integration (marked with AI warning)
   224→
   225→#### Contributing to mdserve Rust Edition Bug
   226→
   227→- **TOP Takeaway**: Edition-gated features can break on stable toolchains
   228→- **The Issue**: Reported on [mdserve #28](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/issues/28#issuecomment-3408716893) that `cargo install mdserve` failed on stable Rust with "let expressions in this position are unstable" - root cause was project using Rust edition 2024 (requires 1.85.0+) where if-let chains are edition-gated despite being stabilized in 1.64.0
   229→- **The Resolution**: Fixed via [PR #29](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/pull/29) by downgrading from edition 2024 to edition 2021, refactoring if-let chains to nested if statements, and adding `rust-version = "1.82.0"` to Cargo.toml
   230→- **Key Learning**: Edition features can surprise users on older stable compilers
   231→

   204→## Diary
   205→
   206→### 2025-10-15
   207→
   208→#### Synchronizing Nvim and Tmux Git Workflows
   209→
   210→- **TOP Takeaway**: Cross-tool consistency requires intentional synchronization
   211→  - Nvim had `:Tig` and `:GitDiff` commands, but tmux had no equivalent
   212→  - Created workflow disparity: git tools only easily accessible from nvim
   213→  - Solution: mirror commands across both tools with sync reminders
   214→- **The Problem**: Inconsistent UX where git workflows were nvim-only
   215→  - No way to invoke tig or git diff directly from tmux command mode
   216→  - Tig windows didn't cleanly exit when closed
   217→  - No documentation linking the two implementations
   218→- **What Worked**:
   219→  - Added tmux command aliases: `:tig/:Tig` and `:gdiff/:Gdiff`
   220→  - [Tmux configuration](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/shared/.tmux.conf#L227-L233)
   221→  - [Nvim sync comments](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/d046eab712dd5e7d4bc1fbb7ff77e224a66cbbce/nvim/nvim_init.lua#L145-L152)
   222→  - Case-insensitive variants for convenience
   223→  - Cross-reference comments in both files warning to keep them synced
   224→  - `:gdiff` pipes through delta for syntax highlighting
   225→  - Clean window closure with `; exit` for tig and `; read` for git diff
   226→- **Key Learning**: When you have parallel implementations, add explicit sync reminders in comments
   227→
   228→#### Improving Telescope Symbol Display
   229→
   230→- **TOP Takeaway**: Default UI configurations often prioritize completeness over usability
   231→  - Telescope LSP symbols were clipping long function/variable names
   232→  - Fixed width columns wasted space on less important data
   233→- **The Solution**: Custom command with adjusted column widths
   234→  - [Implementation for Tags and BTags](https://github.com/idvorkin/settings/blob/a31b2e54ca20747900d65598ab84b575352dc728/nvim/nvim_plugins.lua#L196-L210)
   235→  - Set `fname_width = 0` (hide filename column)
   236→  - Set `symbol_width = 80` (show full symbol names)
   237→  - Set `symbol_type_width = 1` (minimize type indicator)
   238→- **Why It Matters**: Prioritizes the data you actually need to see (symbol names) over metadata
   239→
   240→#### Writing Jung's Self vs Ego Framework
   241→
   242→- **TOP Takeaway**: AI-assisted writing for synthesis and structure
   243→  - Created comprehensive post on Jung's Ego-Self relationship
   244→  - [The post: jung-self-ego.md](https://github.com/idvorkin/idvorkin.github.io/blob/d088a41e6d587b9d08b699155226336a6454af11/_d/jung-self-ego.md)
   245→  - Multiple commit iterations to refine structure and content
   246→  - Added quadrant matrix visualization for the four-stage cycle
   247→- **The Content**:
   248→  - Ego as social operating system vs Self as authentic totality
   249→  - Four-stage cycle: Ego Inflation → Ego Deflation → Dialogue → Integration
   250→  - Practical signs and practices for both states
   251→  - Connected to existing posts on mindfulness, regrets, identity
   252→- **AI Role**: Helped structure framework, expand concepts, maintain consistency
   253→  - Still needs personal experience integration (marked with AI warning)
   254→
   255→#### Contributing to mdserve Rust Edition Bug
   256→
   257→- **TOP Takeaway**: Edition-gated features can break on stable toolchains
   258→- **The Issue**: [mdserve #28](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/issues/28#issuecomment-3408716893)
   259→  - `cargo install mdserve` failed on stable Rust
   260→  - Error: "let expressions in this position are unstable"
   261→  - Root cause: project used Rust edition 2024 (requires 1.85.0+)
   262→  - If-let chains stabilized in 1.64.0 but remain edition-gated
   263→- **The Resolution**: [PR #29](https://github.com/jfernandez/mdserve/pull/29)
   264→  - Downgraded from edition 2024 to edition 2021
   265→  - Refactored if-let chains to nested if statements
   266→  - Added `rust-version = "1.82.0"` to Cargo.toml for version enforcement
   267→- **Key Learning**: Edition features can surprise users on older stable compilers
   268→
   269→#### Adding Historical Christian Ethics Content
   270→

   272→- **The Addition**: [14 signs of being a Christian from ~300 AD](https://github.com/idvorkin/idvorkin.github.io/blob/5a1667096fa71a30505f8b7663c49a6bc70f5cbf/_d/religion.md#L123-L170)
   273→  - Text possibly from Lactantius
   274→  - Mapped 14 signs to personal affirmations
   275→  - Organized under themes: mercy, presence, discipline
   276→  - Connected historical religious ethics to secular spirituality

   269→- **TOP Takeaway**: Switch from tactical to strategic

   271→  - I had to figure out it was hanging at the system level (spent lots of rounds trying to get Claude to guess, it failed and kept thinking I was stuck in a semaphore)
   272→  - Once I came up with system issue, it ran all commands and found the issue
   273→  - The fix didn't work, but I can try again later
   274→- **The Problem**: `changes.py` script hanging indefinitely during subprocess operations
   275→- **The Root Cause**: Three-way deadlock between gRPC's DNS initialization, macOS dyld locking, and fork preparation handlers
   276→  - [Debugging transcript overview](https://gist.github.com/idvorkin/591ff244147a10f53d7495d262c94682#file-a_nlp--overview-md)

   278→  - [Timing debug info](https://gist.github.com/idvorkin/591ff244147a10f53d7495d262c94682#file-zzz_timing_debug-md)
   279→- **What Claude Tried**:
   280→  - `grpc.experimental.fork_support()` → failed
   281→  - Switched Google GenAI models to REST transport → partially worked, revealed HTTP timeout issues
   282→  - Discovered semaphore starvation (HTTP calls holding slots indefinitely)
   283→  - **Final solution**: Disabled Google/Gemini models by default to eliminate the gRPC thread pool
   284→- Full writeup: [stuck-investigate.md](https://github.com/idvorkin/nlp/blob/ed783b2aebf9bdad2de7fedcec3a9ba9e723e7f8/docs/stuck-investigate.md)
